<summary>
• **Threshold Nets**:
	• • Obtained by assigning weights to nodes and connecting those whose combined weights exceed a threshold.
	• • Can produce a wide variety of important architectures, from star graphs to complete graphs.
	• • Studied extensively in graph theory and recently by physicists.
	• • Can be elegantly encoded by a two-letter sequence, corresponding to two types of nodes.
	• • Nodes of type A connect to none of the existing nodes, while nodes of type B connect to all existing nodes.
• **Sequence Nets**:
	• • A broader class of nets constructed from a sequence formed from two or more letters by deterministic rules of connectivity.
	• • • Modularity: Each additional letter to the alphabet allows for an increase of one link in the net's diameter.
	• • • Easily computable structural measures, including degree distribution, triangles, betweenness centrality, and the spectrum and eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian.
	• • • High degree of compressibility.
	• • • Natural ordering: Any ensemble of sequence nets admits a natural ordering by listing them alphabetically according to their sequences.
• **Two-Letter Sequence Nets**:
	• • Three equivalence classes, including threshold nets, which have the highest level of symmetry.
	• • • Remaining two classes also exhibit high modularity and easily computable structural properties.
	• • • Can be related to a generalized form of threshold nets, where the difference rather than the sum of the weights is compared to the threshold.
• **Three-Letter Sequence Nets**:
	• • 30 distinct equivalence classes, including a natural extension of threshold nets.
	• • • At least some can be mapped into threshold nets with two thresholds.
	• • • Diameter grows linearly with the number of letters in the alphabet, reaching 3 or 4 for a 3-letter alphabet.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Variable Selection Methods**: Variable selection methods based on penalty theory have received great attention in high-dimensional data analysis. A principled approach is due to the Lasso of Tibshirani, which uses the L1-norm penalty. Tibshirani also pointed out that the Lasso estimate can be viewed as the mode of the posterior distribution. The L1 penalty can be transformed into the Laplace prior, which can be expressed as a Gaussian scale mixture. This has led to Bayesian developments of the Lasso and its variants.
• **Nonconvex Penalization**: There has also been work on nonconvex penalization under a parametric Bayesian framework. Polson and Scott derived their Local Linear Approximation (LLA) algorithm by combining the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm with an inverse Laplace transform. They showed that the nonconvex penalty with a specific form can be obtained by mixing the Laplace distribution with a stable density. Other authors have shown that the prior induced from a penalty, called the nonconvex log penalty, has an interpretation as a scale mixture of Laplace distributions with an inverse gamma mixing distribution.
• **Compound Poisson Subordinators**: In this paper, the authors further study the application of subordinators in Bayesian nonconvex penalization problems under supervised learning scenarios. They model latent shrinkage parameters using subordinators, which are defined as stochastic processes of regularization parameters. The authors consider two families of compound Poisson subordinators: continuous compound Poisson subordinators based on a gamma random variable and discrete compound Poisson subordinators based on a logarithmic random variable. They show that both the gamma and Poisson subordinators are limiting cases of these two families of the compound Poisson subordinators.
</summary>

			+ - Imaginary axis evaluation for numerical efficiency

		- • Nonanalyticity in current-velocity relation at temperature Tc
			+ - Anisotropy in nonlinear current as a function of superfluid velocity direction

			+ - Integration of bands and response to inter- and intraband impurities

<summary>
• **Time Series Classification**: One of the most important tasks in time series data mining.
  • **1-NN with DTW**: A well-known and effective classifier for time series data.
    • **DTW Distance**: Measures dissimilarity between two time series.
    • **Sakoe-Chiba Band (SC Band)**: Speeds up DTW calculation and acts as a global constraint.
    • **Ratanamahatana-Keogh Band (RK Band)**: Generalizes global constraint model, allows multi bands for each class.
• **Challenges in Global Constraint Selection**:
  • **SC Band**: Fixed width (10% of time series length), may not be optimal for all data.
  • **RK Band**: Requires learning algorithm to discover best multi RK bands, prone to overfitting.
• **Proposed Solutions**:
  • **Band Boundary Extraction**: Uses DTW distance matrix to find optimal band boundaries.
  • **Iterative Learning**: Adjusts band structures based on silhouette index for better prediction accuracy.
• **Classification Process**:
  • **1-NN with DTW and Optimal Band**: Classifies unlabeled data using discovered band and DTW distance.
  • **LB_Keogh Lower Bound**: Speeds up classification process.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Standard Model and Higgs Boson Discovery**
	+ The Standard Model (SM) has been successful in describing particle physics at the electroweak scale.
	+ The ATLAS and CMS collaborations at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) have discovered a new particle consistent with the SM Higgs boson, strengthening the correctness of the SM.
	+ So far, no explicit evidence of physics beyond the SM has been reported from the LHC.
* **Muon Anomalous Magnetic Moment**
	+ There is an anomaly in the muon anomalous magnetic moment (g-2), which has been precisely measured experimentally and compared with state-of-the-art theoretical predictions.
	+ The estimated discrepancies between SM predictions and the measured value are consistently more than 3σ.
	+ While it's too early to conclude that this anomaly is evidence of new physics beyond the SM, it is expected that new particles and interactions related to the muon sector could be involved.
* **New Gauge Interaction for Muon**
	+ The possibility that the muon has a new gauge interaction beyond the SM is explored in this paper.
	+ The charge assignments and renormalizable terms in the Lagrangian that contribute to lepton masses are given.
	+ The neutrino mass is determined from yukawa couplings, Majorana masses, and Dirac mass terms.
* **Lepton Symmetry Breaking and Baryon Asymmetry**
	+ Interactions given by the mass terms break the lepton symmetry.
	+ The baryon asymmetry is washed out if both the lepton number violation and the sphaleron process are important simultaneously.
	+ Two possibilities are considered to avoid the washout: small @xmath30 or small Majorana masses.
* **Constraints on Parameters**
	+ The sphaleron process is efficient only at temperatures above the electroweak scale.
	+ If the baryon asymmetry is produced above the electroweak scale, constraints on the parameters in the mass terms are calculated.
	+ The most efficient interaction that induces symmetry violation by the Majorana masses is shown, and its rate is given.
* **Right-Handed Neutrino Decay**
	+ The right-handed neutrinos are light and weakly coupled, so their lifetimes are calculated.
	+ The most important decay channel is given by the diagram shown in the text.
	+ The decay of the right-handed neutrinos is efficient around the temperature of 100 GeV, and

<summary>
• **Astrophysical Phenomenon: Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs)**
  • Powerful flashes of gamma-rays lasting from less than one second to tens of seconds
  • Isotropic distribution in the sky, observed above the terrestrial atmosphere with x-ray detectors aboard satellites
  • Long GRBs are at cosmological distances, with measured red shifts up to 4.5
• **Energy Release and Possible Explanations**
  • Huge energy releases, up to 10^18 erg (assuming isotropic emission)
  • Most likely candidates: collapse of a very massive star (hypernova) and coalescence of one compact binary system
  • Emission of gravitational waves (GWs) expected to be associated with these events
• **Gravitational Wave Bursts**
  • Duration predicted to be of the order of a few milliseconds for various sources
  • Detectable by present resonant detectors at distances of GRB sources (up to 19 Gpc)
  • Amplitude of GW burst associated with total conversion of 1-2 solar masses should have amplitude of the order of 10^-21
• **Detection Challenges and Correlation Study**
  • Detection of a gravitational signal associated with a single GRB appears hopeless
  • Detection of a signal associated with the sum of many events is more realistic
  • Study of correlations between GRB events and GW signals from NAUTILUS and EXPLORER detectors
• **Correlation Analysis Method**
  • Algorithm based on cross-correlating the outputs of two GW detectors
  • Deals with the difference between emission times for GRB and GW phenomena
  • Unmodelled noise also considered in the analysis
• **Experimental Setup and Detectors**
  • Two resonant bar detectors: EXPLORER (since 1990, at CERN) and NAUTILUS (since 1995, at INFN Frascati)
  • Main characteristics: resonant frequencies, bandwidth, and improved readout system for EXPLORER
• **Bayesian Analysis and Results**
  • Bayesian approach used to infer GW amplitude and energy
  • Jeffreys prior used for GW amplitude, with a cut-off at a given value
  • Expected value and standard deviation for GW amplitude obtained from the probability density function
• **Upper Limits and Likelihood**
  • Upper limit defined as the value below which there is a given probability for the amplitude

<summary>
• **Challenges in Scientific Research Publication Selection**
  • Vast amount of publications
  • Difficulty in selecting high-quality, original, and relevant works
  • Citation mechanism as a discovery tool
• **Citation as a Measure of Scientific Credibility**
  • Number of citations as an estimate of scientific credibility
  • Limitations: unnoticed or forgotten publications
• **Citation Distribution and Preferential Attachment**
  • Power-law distribution of citation counts
  • Preferential attachment process: highly cited papers receive more citations
• **Modeling Citation Networks**
  • Existing models focus on total citations, not issuing publications
  • Proposed model considers two research areas and cross-linking between them
• **Model Definition and Analysis**
  • Initial conditions: two networks with no cross-links
  • Growth mechanism: simultaneous addition of new nodes with preferential attachment
  • Rate equation approach for analysis
• **Model Findings**
  • Power-law distribution for total in-degree, intra-links, and cross-links
  • Exponents depend on average in-degree, initial attractiveness, and coupling parameters
  • Weak coupling case recovers known exponents for intra-links and cross-links
• **Applications and Limitations**
  • Model applicable to citation networks and human sexual contact networks
  • Empirical studies needed to validate findings for cross-link distributions
  • Model flexibility allows representation of various complex systems
</summary>

<summary>
• The theoretical description of hadron production at large transverse momentum involves two steps: hard scattering of partons followed by fragmentation.
	• The first step is calculable in perturbative QCD, while the second step uses fragmentation functions determined phenomenologically.
	• Recent findings show that recombination of partons is more appropriate than fragmentation for producing particles at intermediate transverse momentum in heavy-ion collisions.
	• The purpose of this paper is to introduce the notion of shower partons and determine their distributions to represent fragmentation functions in terms of recombination.
	• The authors aim to quantify the properties of shower partons and illustrate their importance in recombination with thermal partons in heavy-ion collisions.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Nonconvex Semidefinite Programming Problem:**
	• The problem involves a nonconvex objective function and matrix-valued mappings with bilinear matrix inequality (BMI) constraints.
	• It has applications in static output feedback controller design and topology optimization.
	• Many attempts have been made to solve these problems using convex semidefinite programming techniques.
• **New Local Optimization Method:**
	• The method approximates the feasible set of the nonconvex problem by a sequence of inner positive semidefinite convex approximation sets.
	• It generalizes the inner convex approximation method from scalar optimization to nonlinear semidefinite programming.
	• The algorithm ensures strict descent using a regularization technique.
• **Applications in Static Output Feedback Control:**
	• The method can be applied to solve problems in static output feedback control, including spectral abscissa optimization, H-infinity optimization, and mixed H2/H-infinity synthesis.
	• It requires an interior starting point, which can be found using procedures proposed in previous work.
	• The method has been tested on several problems from the COMPETITION library and compared with other methods.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Parallel Chip-Firing Game**:
	• • A periodic automaton on graphs where vertices, each with non-negative chips, fire one chip to each neighbor if possible.
	• • Rules: At the beginning, each vertex has a non-negative number of chips. At each move, if a vertex has at least as many chips as neighbors, it fires one chip to each neighbor. All vertices fire simultaneously.
	• • Notation: Let @xmath4 be a graph, @xmath9 a position, @xmath11 the step operator, @xmath13 the complement of @xmath9, @xmath14 the position after @xmath16 steps.
	• • Period and Transient Length: The minimal positive integer @xmath17 such that @xmath19 for large enough @xmath18 is the period of @xmath9. The minimal @xmath18 such that @xmath19 is the transient length of @xmath9.
• **History and Connections**:
	• • Introduced by Bitar and Goles in 1992 as a special case of the general chip-firing game.
	• • Connections to number theory, algebra, combinatorics, and cellular automata.
	• • Simulates classical computer gates and a pile of particles falling.
	• • Models the deterministic fixed-energy sandpile and spatially extended dynamical systems.
• **Periods on Trees and Complete Graphs**:
	• • Periods on trees: 1 or 2.
	• • Periods on complete graphs: At most 4, proven by Levine in 2008.
	• • Kominers and Kominers showed that all connected graphs satisfying @xmath23 have period 1.
• **Periods on Complete Bipartite Graphs**:
	• • Possible periods: @xmath32 or @xmath33.
	• • Constructed games with such periods.
	• • All periods from @xmath293 to @xmath294 are achievable on complete @xmath2-partite graphs.
• **Future Research Directions**:
	• • Prove Bitar's conjecture for more graphs.
	• • Bound periods of positions on vertex-regular graphs and more general bipartite graphs.
	• • Investigate the relationship between period lengths and subcycle lengths.
	• • Study the implications of reducing the parallel chip-firing game.

<summary>
* **Renormalization of the Standard Model (SM) and Models with Physics Beyond the SM:**
	+ The SM is renormalized using three input parameters: the muon decay constant, the Z boson mass, and the fine structure constant at zero momentum.
	+ The SM tree-level relation between the W and Z boson masses is satisfied, and the weak mixing angle is not a free parameter but derived from the other parameters.
	+ The counterterms for the gauge boson masses and the weak mixing angle are given by specific expressions.
* **Models with Higgs Particles in Representations Other Than Doublets and Singlets:**
	+ These models have more parameters in the gauge/higgs sector than the SM.
	+ The SM tree-level relation between the W and Z boson masses no longer holds, and when the theory is renormalized at one loop, these models require extra input parameters.
	+ Phenomenological studies have considered the contributions of new physics at one loop plus the tree-level contributions of the new physics.
* **Two Specific Examples with Higgs Particles at Tree Level:**
	+ The SM with an additional real scalar triplet and the minimal left-right symmetric model are discussed.
	+ It is demonstrated that the procedure of considering the contributions of new physics at one loop plus the tree-level contributions of new physics is incorrect in these models.
	+ The SM is not recovered even if the scale of new physics becomes much larger than the electroweak scale.
</summary>

<summary>
• The text discusses the uniformization of log-Riemann surfaces of finite type, which are given by a pair of a compact Riemann surface and a meromorphic function with exponential singularities at the punctures.
	• The meromorphic function has essential singularities at the punctures, which are of a specific type called exponential singularities.
	• The uniformization theorems imply that a log-Riemann surface of finite type is given by a pair of a compact Riemann surface and a meromorphic function on the punctured surface with exponential singularities at the punctures.
	• The text also introduces the notion of an exp-algebraic curve, which is a pair of a compact Riemann surface and equivalence classes of germs of meromorphic functions modulo germs of holomorphic functions, with poles of orders at points.
	• The relevant spaces of functions and 1-forms with exponential singularities at the points can be defined using the types of the exponential singularities.
	• The text shows how to associate a degree zero line bundle with a meromorphic connection to an exp-algebraic curve.
	• The connection form of the line bundle near a point is given by a specific formula, which determines the exp-algebraic curve.

	• The text proves a Torelli-type theorem for exp-algebraic curves, which states that two exp-algebraic curves with the same underlying Riemann surface and the same set of punctures are isomorphic if the line bundles are isomorphic and the induced isomorphism maps the canonical sections to each other.

<summary>
• The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems in the crystal lattice.
	+ The problems of the hydrodynamic limit have been studied intensively in the case where the underlying space is the euclidean lattice.
	+ The paper extends these problems to the case where the underlying space has geometric structures: the crystal lattice.
	+ The crystal lattice is a generalization of classical lattice, the square lattice, the triangular lattice, the hexagonal lattice, the kagom lattice, and the diamond lattice.
	+ The paper motivates to study these problems by mentioning the relevance to statistical mechanics and hydrodynamics.
	+ The hydrodynamic limit for the exclusion process is one of the most studied models in this context.
	+ The paper gives an example of the exclusion process in the integer lattice, which is a prototype of the results.
	+ The paper formulates the symmetric simple exclusion process and the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process in crystal lattices.
	+ The main theorem of the paper states that the hydrodynamic limit for these processes on the crystal lattice is obtained as an extension of the one on the euclidean lattice.
	+ The paper reviews the outline of the proof for the euclidean lattice, following the method by Guo, Papanicolaou, and Varadhan.
	+ The paper looks over the outline of the proof for the crystal lattice, highlighting the two main points of difference: the convergence of the laplacian and the local ergodic theorem.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Harmonic Maps**:
	• • Initiated by Fuller, Nash, and Sampson
	• • Existence first proven by Eells and Sampson
	• • Critical points of energy functional between Riemannian/Pseudo-Riemannian manifolds
	• • Trace of second fundamental form vanishes
• **Energy and Tension Field**:
	• • Energy density: E(u) = (1/2) ||du||^2
	• • Tension field: τ(u) = trace(∇du)
	• • Harmonic map: τ(u) = 0
• **Index and Stability**:
	• • Index: dimension of subspace where Hessian is negative definite
	• • Stable: index = 0, unstable: index > 0
	• • Decomposition into vertical and horizontal spaces
• **Horizontal Conformality**:
	• • Horizontally conformal: rank of dφ|_H is zero or surjective and conformal
	• • Critical points: rank = 0, regular points: rank > 0
	• • Premise acknowledged in CFD, minimal surface theory, string theory, gravity, and QFT
• **Pseudo-Riemannian Manifolds**:
	• • Different behavior compared to Riemannian manifolds
	• • Restricted classes for study
	• • Most works between Riemannian manifolds
• **Paper Organization**:
	• • Sect. [Prem]: Basic definitions (almost para-Hermitian, almost paracontact, normal almost paracontact)
	• • Sect. [Paraholo]: Paraholomorphic maps, tension field in para-Hermitian and para-Sasakian manifolds
	• • Sect. [Parap]: Parapluriharmonic maps, necessary and sufficient conditions, example
</summary>

<summary>
* **Star Formation Rate (SFR) and Galaxy Evolution:**
	+ SFR sets the rate at which galaxies grow and evolve.
	+ Large-scale simulations show that unregulated star formation leads to an overabundance of high-mass galaxies.
	+ Some process must stop or "quench" star formation before galaxies grow too big.
	+ Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) are thought to play a role in this process.
* **SMBHs and AGN Feedback:**
	+ SMBHs grow through accretion of cold material, which is then converted into radiation across the electromagnetic spectrum.
	+ AGN can deposit this energy into the interstellar medium (ISM) of their host galaxy through jets or powerful outflows, heating the gas or removing it altogether.
	+ Indirect evidence suggests a strong coevolution of the host galaxy and SMBH.
	+ However, the exact mechanism of AGN feedback and its role in galaxy evolution remains debated.
* **AGN Feedback and SFR:**
	+ Evidence for AGN feedback should also manifest itself in the SFR of its host galaxy.
	+ Accurate estimates of the SFR in AGN host galaxies are challenging due to contamination from the central AGN.
	+ Many studies turn to the infrared (IR) regime, where dust re-emits the stellar light from young stars.
	+ Dust fills the ISM and plays an important part in the heating and cooling of the ISM and the general physics of the galaxy.
* **Herschel Space Observatory and AGN:**
	+ The Herschel Space Observatory has greatly expanded our knowledge of the IR universe and provided a window into the far-IR properties of galaxies.
	+ However, before Herschel, the far-IR spectral energy distribution (SED) was limited to wavelengths below 120 μm, except for studies of small samples of the brightest galaxies using ground-based instruments.
	+ Herschel has pushed into the submillimeter range with observations in the 250, 350, and 500 μm wavebands, probing the Rayleigh-Jeans tail of the modified blackbody that accurately describes the broadband far-IR SED of galaxies.
	+ These wavebands are crucial for measuring dust properties and estimating the SFR of AGN host galaxies.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Fundamental Group of Plane Curves:**
  - • Used as a topological invariant for distinguishing connected components of moduli space of smooth projective surfaces.
  - • Zariski-Lefschetz hyperplane section theorem relates fundamental groups of complements of curves to those of hypersurfaces.
  - • Different needs arise in searching for Zariski pairs and studying new finite non-abelian groups as fundamental groups of complements of plane curves.
• **Conjugation-Free Geometric Presentations:**
  - • Defined for fundamental groups of affine or projective complements of line arrangements with a specific set of generators and relations.
  - • Fan's result shows that if the graph associated to the arrangement is acyclic, then the corresponding fundamental group has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
  - • The aim of the paper is to attack the problem of which line arrangements have a fundamental group with a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
• **Arrangements with Conjugation-Free Geometric Presentations:**
  - • The fundamental group of the affine Ceva arrangement (also known as the braid arrangement) has no conjugation-free geometric presentation.
  - • The main result is that the fundamental group of a family of real arrangements, where the graph is a union of disjoint cycles of any length and has no line with more than two multiple points, has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
  - • The exact group structure is given for an arrangement of lines whose graph is a cycle of length 3, where all the multiple points are of multiplicity 3.
• **Relation to Other Families of Arrangements:**
  - • The family of arrangements with a conjugation-free geometric presentation is broader than the family of simple arrangements.
  - • It is not known whether there exists a simple arrangement whose fundamental group has no conjugation-free geometric presentation.
  - • Conjugation-free geometric presentations are complemented positive presentations, which have all the good properties induced by completeness.
• **Future Work:**
  - • The paper discusses the subject of conjugation-free geometric presentations that are complete in a different paper.
  - • The paper is organized into sections that give a quick survey of techniques used throughout the paper, present the main result for real arrangements whose graph has a unique cycle of length 3, and deal with the general case of arrangements whose graphs are unions of disjoint cycles.
  - • The computation of the fundamental group of the complement of real line arrangements is based on the Moishezon-Teicher method and the van Kampen theorem.
</summary

		- • Electron addition and removal energies change upon adsorption on a substrate
		- • Image charge accumulated on the substrate alters addition or removal energy of charge carriers from the molecule
• **Quasiparticle (QP) Description and Limitations**
	+ • Common way to calculate addition and removal energies
		- • Ignores relaxation of molecular orbitals due to electron addition or removal
		- • Relative alignment of metal Fermi level with LUMO and HOMO of a molecule used as removal energy
	+ • Adequacy of QP description depends on the level of theory used to calculate energy levels of HOMO and LUMO
		- • Density functional theory (DFT) has limitations in calculating QP energies
			- • Local and semi-local approximations (LDA, GGA) perform poorly for HOMO level
			- • Hybrid functionals, self-interaction corrected functionals, and range-separated functionals show encouraging results
	+ • Calculation of energy levels alignment of a molecule in proximity of a metal presents additional problems
		- • Formation of image charge has a non-local nature
		- • Most functionals fail to capture this effect, leading to minimal change in HOMO and LUMO positions
• **Constrained Density Functional Theory (CDFT) Approach**
	+ • Alternative to quasiparticle description for calculating charge transfer energies
		- • Transfers one electron from molecule to substrate (or vice versa) and calculates energy difference
		- • Avoids calculation of QP spectrum and replaces it with a series of total energy calculations for different charge distributions

* **Method for studying atomic properties in excited states**
	+ Two-color modulation transfer spectroscopy
	+ Uses two lasers (pump and probe) counter-propagating through a thermal vapor
	+ Pump laser connects ground state to an intermediate state, probe laser scans over desired energy manifold
	+ Monitors absorption of pump laser as a function of probe laser detuning
* **Advantages of the method**
	+ Overcomes low signal-to-noise ratio and non-availability of detectors at desired wavelength
	+ Burns a hole in the atomic ground state population, generating sub-Doppler peaks
	+ Sidebands at the side of atomic resonances serve as an in-situ ruler for energy separations or to lock laser frequency to excited transition
* **Applications of the method**
	+ Precise measurements in higher excited states
	+ Studies of atomic properties in excited states
	+ Further pushing experimental precision and theoretical work in excited atomic states
* **Support and acknowledgments**
	+ Supported by NSF
	+ A.P.G. thanks E. Gomez and P. Barberis for discussions and help on the theory of three-level atoms
</summary>

<summary>
* **Central Exclusive Production (CEP) of Higgs Boson at LHC**
	+ **Focus of Interest**: Central exclusive production (CEP) process, where protons remain intact and the central system is separated by a large rapidity gap.
	+ **Quantum Numbers**: Observation of any particle in the CEP channel provides a direct observation of its quantum numbers.
	+ **Mass Measurement**: Mass of the centrally produced particle can be measured regardless of its decay products by detecting the outgoing protons and measuring their energy loss accurately.
	+ **Forward Proton Detectors**: Proposed to be installed around ATLAS and CMS to detect central systems in the approximate mass range of 70 GeV.
	+ **Signal and Background Events**: Simulated with parton showering and hadronisation effects using EXHUME v1.3.4, which contains a direct implementation of the Khoze, Martin, and Ryskin (KMR) calculation of the CEP process.
	+ **Signal Cross Section**: Cross section for the CEP of a standard model Higgs boson decaying to b-quarks varies from 1.86 fb (MRST2002NLO) to 7.38 fb (CTEQ6L1) due to uncertainties in parton distribution functions (PDFs) and the soft survival factor.
	+ **Background Processes**: Broken down into three categories: central exclusive di-jet production, double pomeron exchange, and overlap events. Central exclusive di-jet backgrounds are the most difficult to deal with, while double pomeron exchange and overlap events can be rejected with high efficiency using exclusivity variables.
	+ **Trigger Strategies**: Proposed to retain a fraction of b-jet events by adopting specific trigger strategies for the currently foreseen level 1 trigger hardware.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Quantum Many-Body System Out of Equilibrium:**
	• Extensive studies have been done on quantum many-body systems out of equilibrium.
	• Many new findings have been made, but many questions still remain unresolved.
	• The dynamics of such systems are difficult to describe generically.
• **Transport of Physical Quantities:**
	• Transport of a physical quantity, such as magnetization, is an important aspect of nonequilibrium dynamics.
	• Magnetization transport in low-dimensional spin systems has gained attention in spintronics and nano-device applications.
• **Theoretical Studies on Transport Properties:**
	• Earlier theoretical studies have shown that transport properties in closed quantum systems differ significantly from their classical counterparts.
	• Current-carrying states have been generated in integrable Hamiltonians to observe their relaxation dynamics.
	• Introduction of magnetization current results in oscillatory behavior and power-law decay of correlations in space.
• **Integrability and Thermalization:**
	• Integrability has become a crucial perspective in studying nonequilibrium phenomena.
	• Integrable systems have restricted dynamics and their relaxation process depends on the initial state.
	• Thermalization was believed to be absent in integrable systems, but recent studies have shown weak thermalization or no thermalization in non-integrable systems.
• **Role of Integrability on Response Functions:**
	• The role of integrability on the behavior of response functions has been put under question.
	• Some quantities in completely integrable systems exhibit thermal behavior, counterintuitive to previous ideas on thermalization.
• **Transport Properties and Integrability:**
	• There is no generic relation between integrability and transport properties.
	• Some preceding works have explored this relation.
• **Relaxation Dynamics of Integrable Quantum Systems:**
	• More investigation is needed in the relaxation dynamics of integrable quantum systems generally followed by a quench.
	• In this article, the dynamics due to transport of transverse magnetization in a quantum Ising chain is studied.
	• The transport properties and the relaxation of magnetization with time are analyzed.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Kepler Mission and Planetary Candidates:**
  • Discovered over 4100 planetary candidates in 3200 systems.
  • Small planets are nearly ubiquitous, with some of the most common being super-Earths to mini-Neptunes.
  • Transition from rocky to non-rocky planets occurs near a radius of ~4 R⊕ and is very sharp.
• **Stellar Multiplicity and Planetary Radii:**
  • Presence of stellar companions affects observed transit depths and derived planetary radii.
  • Kepler pipeline treats each candidate host star as single, introducing systematic uncertainty.
  • Recent work suggests a non-negligible fraction of Kepler host stars may be multiples.
• **Effects of Undetected Companions:**
  • Undetected companions cause planetary radii to be systematically too small.
  • Observed radii will be underestimated by a factor of ~1.5 on average if stars are assumed single.
  • Overestimation of planet bulk density by a factor of ~1.7.
• **Vetting with Radial Velocity and High-Resolution Imaging:**
  • Radial velocity and high-resolution imaging can reduce the fraction of undetected companions.
  • Mean correction factor reduced to ~1.1 if stars are vetted.
  • Benefit is even greater for K2 and TESS targets, which are closer and brighter.
• **Occurrence Rates and Earth-Sized Planets:**
  • Undetected companions may affect the determination of occurrence rates.
  • Earth-sized planet fraction may be overestimated by up to 20% if stars are assumed single.
  • Giant planet fraction may be underestimated by up to 30%.
• **Recommendations:**
  • Stellar companion detections (or lack thereof) must be considered for final occurrence rate determination.
  • Single epoch high-resolution imaging may be most effective for K2 and TESS candidates.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Star Formation and Cluster Evolution:**
  • Most stars form in star clusters.
  • Only a modest percentage of gas turns into stars during cluster formation.
  • Young clusters initially contain gas and stars.
  • Stellar winds and supernovae expel gas, leaving clusters out of equilibrium.
  • This process is well understood theoretically but has received little consideration in observational studies.
• **Constraints on Initial Mass Function (IMF):**
  • Studies have attempted to constrain the IMF by measuring velocity dispersion and half-mass radius of young clusters.
  • Some studies report non-standard IMFs, while others find standard IMFs.
  • Bastian et al. (2006) noted an age dependence in IMF fits, with younger clusters showing more scatter.
• **Present Work:**
  • Investigates three young massive clusters: M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1.
  • Finds evidence that these clusters are likely not in dynamical equilibrium due to rapid gas loss.
  • Suggests that claims of varying stellar IMFs may be incorrect due to clusters not being in virial equilibrium.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Quantum Fluctuation, Tunneling, and Decoherence in a Polychromatically Driven Double-Well System**
  • **Quantum Dynamics**
    • • Transition Probability
      • - Enhanced by increasing number of frequency components
      • - Suppressed by coherent driving in certain parameter regime
    • • Degree of Coherence
      • - Measures difference between coherent and incoherent motions
      • - Decreases with increasing perturbation strength and number of frequency components
  • **Chaos and Tunneling**
    • • Chaos-Assisted Tunneling
      • - Reduced tunneling period due to appearance of stochastic layer near separatrix
      • - Enhanced tunneling rate in coherent oscillation regime
    • • Chaos-Induced Delocalization
      • - Wave packet incoherently spreads and never returns to Gaussian shape
      • - Decoherence and dissipation effects caused by coupling to other degrees of freedom
  • **Numerical Results**
    • • Time-Dependence of Transition Probability
      • - Coherent and irregular motions observed
      • - Tunneling contribution not significant for large perturbation strength and/or number of frequency components
    • • Phase Space Dynamics
      • - Uncertainty product as a measure of quantum fluctuation
      • - Different behavior between polychromatic and stochastic perturbations
</summary>

<summary>
* **Quantum Electrodynamics and Casimir Effect**
	+ * Quantum fluctuations of electric and magnetic fields give rise to zero-point energy.
	+ * Casimir predicted attraction between two neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum.
	+ * Plates act as a cavity where only specific electromagnetic modes exist.
	+ * Zero-point energy is smaller at close distances, leading to attraction.
* **Lifshitz Theory and Generalization**
	+ * Lifshitz, Dzyaloshinskii, and Pitaevskii generalized Casimir's theory to isotropic dielectrics.
	+ * Force between uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions can be derived.
	+ * At short distances, force reduces to non-retarded van der Waals force.
	+ * Two plates made of the same material always attract, regardless of the medium.
* **Anisotropic Materials and Torque**
	+ * Parseghian, Weiss, and Barash predicted torque between anisotropic materials.
	+ * Torque develops between two parallel birefringent slabs in an isotropic medium.
	+ * Anisotropy of zero-point energy generates torque, making plates rotate towards configurations of smaller energy.
	+ * Less attention has been devoted to this effect, with no experimental attempts or numerical calculations.
* **Experimental Validation of Torque**
	+ * Authors calculate torque magnitude for specific materials and discuss possible experimental validations.
	+ * Consider a small birefringent disk (quartz or calcite) parallel to a barium titanate plate in vacuum.
	+ * Torque is within the sensitivity of available instrumentation at sub-micron distances.
	+ * Measurement of rotation may be challenging due to tendency of surfaces to stick together.
* **Simplified Experimental Approach**
	+ * Propose an experiment with the disk floating on top of the plate in liquid ethanol.
	+ * Retarded van der Waals force between the two birefringent slabs is repulsive.
	+ * Disk floats at a distance of approximately 100 nm, where its weight is counterbalanced by van der Waals repulsion.
	+ * Disk is free to rotate, sensitive to small driving torques.
* **Calculations and Results**
	+ * Calculate torque as a function of angle and distance for quartz-batio38 and calcite-batio38 configurations.
	+ * Maximum torque occurs at specific angles, with different signs for quartz and calcite.

<summary>
* **Source Document:**
	+ **Purpose:** To solve a conformal field theory (CFT) amounts to finding its spectrum and 3-point correlation functions.
	+ **Method:** Using operator product expansion (OPE) to find higher point functions from 3-point functions.
	+ **Deformation:** To study the effect of deforming a CFT with a marginal or irrelevant operator.
	+ **Anomalous Dimensions:** Finding the anomalous dimensions of operators in the deformed theory.
	+ **Couplings:** Computing the couplings in 3-point correlation functions.
	+ **Examples:** Considering the deformation of 4D super-Yang-Mills (SYM) theory by the Lagrangian operator.
	+ **Integrability:** Exploring new methods to compute couplings using integrability techniques.
	+ **Ads/CFT Duality:** Computing 3-point correlation functions at strong coupling using the AdS/CFT duality.
* **Main Results:**
	+ **Deformed Theory:** The deformation introduces new divergences in the renormalized operators of the critical theory, determined by the couplings.
	+ **Anomalous Dimension Matrix:** The deformed anomalous dimension matrix can be used to relate the couplings to the couplings in the 3-point function.
	+ **Couplings Computation:** The couplings can be computed by diagonalizing the anomalous dimension matrix of the critical theory and finding the action of the perturbation matrix on the bare operators.
	+ **SYM Theory:** The method is applied to the deformation of 4D SYM theory by the Lagrangian operator, and the couplings are computed up to order 116 in the t'Hooft coupling.
	+ **Ads/CFT Duality:** The method is extended to compute 3-point correlation functions involving an additional chiral operator, with the dilaton field as an example.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Cosmological Observations and Dark Energy**
	+ Cosmological observations from Type Ia supernovae, cosmic microwave background radiation, and large-scale structure indicate that the universe is currently in an accelerating phase.
	+ This acceleration is attributed to a form of dark energy (DE) with negative pressure.
	+ The simplest candidate for DE is the cosmological constant, but it faces the cosmological constant problem.
	+ The Lambda-CDM paradigm may also suffer from the age problem, and current data slightly favors an evolving DE.
* **Dark Energy Models**
	+ Several DE models have been proposed, such as quintessence, phantom, k-essence, tachyon, quintom, chaplygin gas, generalized chaplygin gas, holographic DE, new agegraphic DE, Ricci DE, etc.
	+ There are also models that induce effective dark energy through modifications of the gravitational sector, like f(R) gravity, gravity with higher curvature invariants, and others.
* **Teleparallel Gravity and Torsion**
	+ Teleparallel gravity is a theory based on the Weitzenbock connection, which describes the gravitational field using torsion instead of curvature.
	+ The torsion tensor contains all the information about the gravitational field, and the teleparallel action is built using its contractions.
	+ The teleparallel equivalent of general relativity (TEGR) is completely equivalent to general relativity at the level of equations but is based on torsion instead of curvature.
* **Modified Teleparallel Gravity**
	+ Starting from TEGR, one can construct gravitational modifications based on torsion by considering a lagrangian density that is a function of the torsion scalar.
	+ The simplest scenario is to consider a lagrangian density that is a function of the torsion scalar, leading to modified teleparallel gravity (MTGR).
	+ The field equations of MTGR are second-order differential equations, making these theories simpler compared to other extended theories of gravity.
* **Big Bang Nucleosynthesis (BBN) and Constraints on MTGR**
	+ BBN occurred between 10^-35 seconds and a few hundred seconds after the Big Bang, when the universe was hot and dense.
	+ BBN describes the sequence of nuclear reactions that yielded the synthesis of light elements and drove the observed universe.
	+ In this work, the authors confront various MTGR models with BBN calculations based on current observational data on primordial abundance of ^4He to extract constraints on their free parameters.
</summary

* **Bidirectional Relay Network:**
	+ *Three-node half-duplex network*
	+ *User 1 and User 2 exchange information via a relay node*
	+ *No direct link between users*
	+ *Time divided into slots, each node transmits codewords spanning one slot or a fraction*
	+ *User-relay and relay-user channels impaired by AWGN with unit variance and block fading*
	+ *Reciprocal channel coefficients in each time slot*
	+ *Relay has two buffers for storing received information*
* **Six Transmission Modes:**
	+ *User 1 to relay (U1R)*
	+ *User 2 to relay (U2R)*
	+ *Relay to user 1 (RU1)*
	+ *Relay to user 2 (RU2)*
	+ *Both users to relay (U1R+U2R)*
	+ *Relay broadcasts to both users (RU1+RU2)*
* **Achievable Rates:**
	+ *Derived for each transmission mode*
	+ *Relay decodes and stores information in buffers*
	+ *Sum rate maximized by optimal mode selection and power allocation policy*
* **Adaptive Mode Selection and Power Allocation:**
	+ *Jointly optimizes transmission mode and transmit powers*
	+ *Given a joint power budget, selects optimal mode and allocates powers*
	+ *Maximizes sum rate of both users*
	+ *Requires instantaneous CSI of involved links and long-term statistics*
	+ *Simulation results confirm proposed protocol outperforms existing protocols*
</summary>

<summary>
• **Acoustic Oscillations as a Standard Ruler:**
	• • The acoustic oscillations imprinted in the matter power spectrum at recombination serve as a standard ruler.
	• • This scale can be accurately calculated based on measurements of the CMB anisotropy power spectrum.
• **Robustness of Low-Redshift Acoustic Oscillations:**
	• • The interpretation of low-redshift acoustic oscillations is robust if the CMB correctly tells us the baryon-photon ratio and the epoch of matter-radiation equality.
	• • These quantities are robustly measured in the CMB, and only their ratio matters, not the actual densities.
• **Sound Horizon and Cosmological Parameters:**
	• • The sound horizon, the comoving distance a sound wave travels, is crucial for the acoustic peak method.
	• • It depends only on the Hubble parameter and the sound speed in the baryon-photon plasma.
• **Impact of Undetected Relativistic Components:**
	• • If the CMB measurements are misled by undetected relativistic particles, the inferences for dark energy from combined CMB and low-redshift survey data sets are unchanged.
	• • However, knowledge of actual densities improves constraints on the Hubble constant.
• **Measuring the Acoustic Scale at Low Redshift:**
	• • Measuring the acoustic scale at low redshift in large galaxy surveys constrains the matter and energy content of the universe.
	• • The prefactors of the sound horizon cancel out, allowing reliable prediction of distance ratios.
• **Searching for Dynamical Shenanigans:**
	• • Measuring the acoustic oscillation scale at high and low redshifts allows searching for dynamical shenanigans between these redshifts.
	• • A photometric-redshift survey over large amounts of sky is an economical route to this goal.
</summary>

* **Main Result**: Every Lindblad evolution with self-adjoint Lindblad operators can be understood as an averaged random unitary evolution.
	+ This result is proven in the main section of the paper.
	+ It allows for the derivation of analytical consequences and the generalization to non-Markovian situations.
* **Analytical Consequences**:
	+ A fast method to solve Master Equations (MEs) is provided, given the unitary solutions.
	+ The Jaynes-Cummings model with phase damping in the rotating-wave approximation is solved as an example.
* **Non-Markovian Regimes**:
	+ The result is generalized to both Markovian and non-Markovian regimes under the same mathematical formalism.
	+ The Lindbladian structure with self-adjoint Lindblad operators is shown to have an origin independent of the Markov approximation.
* **Intrinsic Decoherence Models**:
	+ The flexibility of the mathematical language employed easily generalizes some intrinsic decoherence models present in the literature.
	+ The random nature of time evolution is proposed as an intrinsic mechanism of decoherence.
* **Physical Interpretations and Comparisons**:
	+ The formalism is discussed under a more physical spirit by proposing a slight generalization of the Jaynes-Cummings model.
	+ The proposed formalism is compared with experimental results in optical cavities and ion traps.
	+ The possibility of intrinsic decoherence phenomena is discussed.
</summary>

• **Transition Layers and Intermediate Stable Layer:**
  - • Transition layers exist due to thermal instability, allowing gas to coexist at different phases with varying temperatures and densities.
  - • An intermediate stable layer can exist between two transition layers, with a nearly uniform temperature, when the incident spectrum is soft enough.
  - • The thickness of the intermediate layer is determined by hydrostatic equilibrium, and its optical depth is typically small.

• **Emission Lines:**
  - • Recombination emission lines are dominant in photoionized plasmas, with radiative recombination followed by cascades as the main formation process.
  - • The flux of a particular line depends on the density of the ion before recombination, the line energy, and the line emissivity.
  - • The emission equivalent width is independent of the density of the medium and the incident flux, making it a unique function of the structure deduced from the hydrostatic and energy balance equations.

• **Reflection Lines:**
  - • Resonance line scattering can result in significant reflected flux, with cross sections much larger than Thomson scattering.
  - • The reflection equivalent width is a few tenths of an ev for strong resonance lines, similar to that of the recombination emission lines.
  - • The appearance of the reflected line spectrum is different from that of the recombination emission spectrum, allowing high-resolution spectroscopic observations to distinguish between the two mechanisms.

<summary>
* **Main Result**: A connected graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and narrow.
	+ **Chordal**: The graph has no cycles of length 3 or less without a chord.
	+ **Claw-Free**: The graph has no induced subgraph of the form K1,4 (a claw).
	+ **Narrow**: Every vertex is distance at most one from every longest shortest path.
* **Algorithm**: A labeling algorithm is introduced to label connected graphs.
	+ **Input**: A connected, chordal, claw-free, and narrow graph.
	+ **Output**: A labeling of the graph.
* **Characterization**: The labeling produced by the algorithm is closed if and only if it satisfies certain properties.
	+ **Interval Property**: For all vertices u and v with u ≤ v, the neighborhood of u in the labeling is complete and equal to the interval [i, j] where i = |{n_g^>}(u)| and j = |{n_g^>}(v)|.
	+ **Closed Property**: The labeling is closed if and only if it satisfies the interval property.
* **Proof**: The proof involves showing that the algorithm produces a closed labeling for chordal, claw-free, and narrow graphs.
	+ **Base Case**: The algorithm labels the first vertex as 1 and labels the remaining vertices in increasing order of degree.
	+ **Inductive Step**: The algorithm labels the vertices in each connected component in increasing order of degree.
	+ **Closed Labeling**: The labeling produced by the algorithm is closed if and only if it satisfies the interval property.
* **Corollary**: A graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and its connected components are narrow.
* **Independence**: The conditions of chordal, claw-free, and narrow are independent.
* **Examples**: Examples of graphs that are chordal and narrow but not claw-free, chordal and claw-free but not narrow, and claw-free and narrow but not chordal are provided.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Methods for calculating resonance states:**
	+ Complex scaling method
	+ Complex absorbing potential method
	+ Density of states (DOS) method
* **Issues with these methods:**
	+ Complex scaling method requires large rotation angle
	+ Complex absorbing potential method produces nonphysical solutions
	+ DOS method provides many approximate values with uncertain accuracy
* **Proposed method:**
	+ Use bundles of states linked by crossings in the variational spectrum
	+ Calculate energy and width using scaling properties of DOS
* **Advantages of the proposed method:**
	+ Linear convergence for small width resonances
	+ Robust against choice of bundles
	+ Improves calculation of resonance energies
* **Limitations of the proposed method:**
	+ May not be applicable when resonances are close together
	+ Lifetime calculation is more subtle and may not converge linearly
* **Future work:**
	+ Investigate convergence properties of resonance energy and lifetime
	+ Understand the appearance of bundles in the spectrum
</summary>

<summary>
• The NCSM/RGM approach, combining microscopic cluster techniques with realistic interactions, has been extended to describe three-body cluster states.
	• This extension is essential for studying nuclear systems with three-body cluster structures, such as two-nucleon halo nuclei, resonant systems, and transfer reactions.
• The method uses a basis of three-body cluster channel states built from the NCSM wave function of each cluster.
	• The many-body problem is mapped onto a system of coupled-channel integral-differential equations, solved using the microscopic R-matrix method on a Lagrange mesh.
• The first results for the ground state and continuum states of 11Be within a 10Be+n+n basis have been presented.
	• The ground state energy is close to convergence, with a difference of approximately 1 MeV due to core excitations not currently included in the NCSM/RGM approach.
	• The wave functions feature an appropriate asymptotic behavior, contrary to bound-state NCSM methods.
• The NCSM/RGM approach is ideal for studying 11Be states in the continuum, as it can describe low-energy phase shifts for different channels.
	• Preliminary results show the experimentally known 11Be resonance and a second low-lying resonance recently measured at GANIL.
• Computing support for this work came from various sources, including LLNL, DOE/SC/NP, NERC, and TRIUMF.
• The work builds upon previous ab initio many-body calculations and is part of ongoing research in the field.
</summary>

<summary>

	• • MnSi films offer interesting magnetic phases and easy integration due to silicon substrate, but have low magnetic ordering temperature.
• **MnGe as a Suitable Candidate**
	• • MnGe (bulk lattice constant of 4.795 Å) has a higher magnetic ordering temperature (170K) compared to MnSi.
	• • MnGe has a helical spin structure with a helix length between 3 nm and 6 nm.
	• • A large topological Hall effect exceeding that of MnSi was observed in MnGe, attributed to a skyrmion phase.
• **Growth of MnGe Thin Films on Si Substrates**
	• • MnGe thin films were grown on Si(111) substrates using a MnSi seedlayer.
	• • Reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD) were used to investigate the structure and morphology of the films.
	• • Magnetization and magnetoresistance measurements were performed to determine the physical properties of the samples.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Thurston's Core Entropy**:
	+ Defined for postcritically finite quadratic polynomials.
	+ Extends continuously to non-postcritically finite parameters with locally connected Julia sets and topologically finite Hubbard trees.
	+ Monotonic along veins in the Mandelbrot set.
• **Computing Core Entropy**:
	+ Thurston's algorithm computes core entropy for rational angles.
	+ A new algorithm computes core entropy for any angle using labeled wedges and infinite graphs.
	+ The algorithm leverages an infinite version of Thurston's algorithm and spectral determinants.

<summary>
• **Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs) and their Origin:**
  - • Detection of X-ray, optical, and radio afterglows from well-localized GRBs confirms their cosmological origin.
  - • The fireball model is strongly favored to explain GRBs.
  - • The nature of GRBs (isotropic fireballs or collimated jets) is still uncertain, affecting the determination of their energetics.
• **Methods to Determine GRB Beaming:**
  - • Analytic solutions suggest that optical afterglows from jetted GRBs should exhibit a break during the relativistic phase.
    - - Some GRBs, like 990123 and 990510, are considered examples of this.
    - - However, detailed numerical studies show that the break is usually smooth and may occur at the trans-relativistic phase.
    - - Other factors, such as electron cooling, dense interstellar medium, or wind environment, can also result in light curve breaks.
  - • Gruzinov argued that optical afterglows from jets can be strongly polarized, up to tens of percents.
    - - Some positive observations have been reported, but polarization can only be observed under specific conditions.
  - • The third method, proposed by Rhoads, involves the detection of orphan afterglows, which are not associated with any detectable GRBs.
    - - The ratio of orphan afterglow rate to GRB rate might allow measurement of the GRB collimation angle.
    - - However, Dalal, Griest, and Pruit argued that measuring the GRB beaming angle using optical orphan searches is extremely difficult.
    - - An interesting result was recently reported by Vanden Berk et al., who discovered a possible optical orphan at z=0.385.
• **Failed Gamma-Ray Bursts (FGRBs):**
  - • FGRBs are baryon-contaminated fireballs with an initial Lorentz factor much less than 100 but still much greater than unity.
  - • Radiation from FGRBs should mainly be in X-ray bands in the initial bursting phase, not in gamma-ray bands.
  - • Bepposax team has reported the discovery of several anomalous events named as fast X-ray transients, X-ray-rich GRBs, or even X-ray GRBs, which resemble usual GRBs except that they are extremely X-ray rich.
    - - Recent good examples include GR

<summary>
* **Material and Properties**
	+ *Layered organic material A3I (AI3) studied since the 1980s*
		- *Reveals low-energy massless Dirac fermions under high pressure (~2 GPa)*
		- *Differences from graphene: tilted Dirac cones, anisotropy, smaller Fermi velocity, charge-ordered phase at ambient pressure*
	+ *Strong electronic correlations expected due to larger effective coupling constant*
	+ *Presence of additional massive carriers near the Fermi level*
	+ *Topological merging of Dirac points expected at high but accessible pressure*
* **Magneto-Transport Measurements**
	+ *High-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes proven experimentally*
	+ *Interplay between massless Dirac fermions and massive carriers at low energy*
	+ *Scattering mechanisms hint at strongly screened interaction potentials or other short-range scatterers*
* **Temperature Dependence and Thermopower**
	+ *Temperature-dependent carrier densities for both Dirac and massive carriers*
	+ *Power-law behavior for mobilities: ~T^0.9 for Dirac carriers, ~T^2.2 for massive carriers*
	+ *Thermopower measurements support two-carrier scenario*
* **Comparison with Graphene**
	+ *AI3 has lower Fermi velocity, larger effective coupling constant, and smaller mobilities compared to graphene*
	+ *AI3 shows coexistence of Dirac and massive carriers, unlike graphene*
</summary>

<summary>
• **Superconducting Gap Structure in Fe-Based Superconductors (Febs):**
	• • The origin of the unconventional superconducting state in Febs is still debated.
	• • Febs can be divided into two subclasses: pnictides and chalcogenides, with the square lattice of iron as the basic element.
	• • The Fermi surface (FS) consists of two hole sheets around the Γ point and two electron sheets around the X and Y points in the two-dimensional Brillouin zone (BZ), corresponding to one Fe per unit cell (the so-called 1-Fe BZ).
• **Spin Response in Normal and Superconducting States of Febs:**
	• • The transverse dynamical spin susceptibility is a matrix in orbital (or band) indices.
	• • In the random phase approximation (RPA), the spin susceptibility is obtained by summing up a series of ladder diagrams.
	• • The physical spin susceptibility is calculated using the interaction matrix and the bare spin susceptibility in the superconducting state.
• **Spin Resonance in Febs:**
	• • Spin resonance appears in the @xmath7 state below the indirect gap scale @xmath3, determined by the sum of gaps on two different Fermi surface sheets connected by the scattering wave vector @xmath2.
	• • For the Fermi surface geometry characteristic to most Febs materials, the indirect gap is either @xmath4 or @xmath5.
	• • If the peak frequency @xmath21 is less than the indirect gap @xmath3, then it is the spin resonance, and the superconducting state has the @xmath7 gap structure.
</summary>

		- • Demonstrated in 1D with Random Dimer Model (RDM) and Dual Random Dimer Model (DRDM)

• **Results and Conclusions**
	+ • 2D-DRDM introduces delocalized states even in higher dimensions

		- • Resonance energy does not depend on system dimensionality
	+ • Weakly interacting Bose gas driven to homogeneity by 2D-DRDM

		- • Enhancement of both near resonance energy of 2D-DRDM single-particle Hamiltonian

<summary>
• **Graph Theory Concepts**:
  • An independent set is a subset of vertices where no two vertices are adjacent.
  • The independence number is the size of the largest independent set.
  • The maximum independent set problem is to find an independent set with the largest number of vertices.
• **Generalized Petersen Graphs**:
  • A generalized Petersen graph is defined by vertex and edge sets based on two integers n and k.
  • The graph has an inner subgraph (on 2k vertices) and an outer cycle (on n vertices).
  • Two vertices are called twins if they are adjacent and the edge between them is called a spoke.
• **Problem and Paper Focus**:
  • The paper aims to study the maximum independent set problem for generalized Petersen graphs.
  • It provides upper and lower bounds, exact values, and proves a conjecture for some cases.
• **Main Results**:
  • An upper bound for the independence number when k is even is presented.
  • Lower bounds are given for even k, and exact values are found for some pairs of n and k.
  • The paper also proves Behsaz-Hatami-Mahmoodian's conjecture for some cases.
</summary>

<summary>
• Quantum key distribution (QKD) is often said to be unconditionally secure.
	+ This means it is secure against any eavesdropping, given certain conditions.
• QKD can be proven to be secure using mathematical models.
	+ These models assume certain conditions, such as mathematical characterization of users' devices and no side-channel.
• The security of QKD relies on the users' devices satisfying these conditions.
	+ This includes mathematical characterization of users' devices and the assumption of no side-channel.
• No one can break the mathematical model of QKD.
	+ However, in practice, it is very difficult for practical QKD systems to meet these requirements.
• Some attacks on QKD have been proposed and demonstrated successfully against practical QKD systems.
	+ These attacks exploit imperfections in the devices.
• To combat these practical attacks, some counter-measures have been proposed.
	+ One of these is the device-independent security proof idea.
• The device-independent security proof is very interesting from a theoretical viewpoint.
	+ However, it can not apply to practical QKD systems where loopholes in testing Bell's inequality cannot be closed.
• The most successful practical attack so far is to exploit the imperfections of the detectors.
	+ This attack is based on the fact that the detectors are not perfect and can make errors.
• The battle-testing of the practical detection unit has attracted many researchers' attention.
	+ This is because the most successful practical attack so far is to exploit the imperfections of the detectors.
• A very simple and promising idea called measurement device independent QKD (MDIQKD) has been proposed.
	+ This scheme is based on a reversed EPR-based QKD protocol, which is equivalent to EPR-based QKD in terms of security.
	+ MDIQKD removes all the potential loopholes of the detectors without sacrificing the performance of standard QKD.
	+ It is shown in the appendix that MDIQKD with infinite number of decoy states and polarization encoding can cover about twice the distance of standard decoyed QKD, which is comparable to EPR-based QKD.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Majorana Fermions (MFs) and Their Detection:**
  - • MFs are real solutions of the Dirac equation and their own antiparticles.
  - • Originally proposed as a model for neutrinos, MFs are now predicted to occur in engineered condensed matter systems.
  - • MFs obey non-Abelian statistics, which is crucial for decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing.
  - • Recent focus is on hosting MFs in exotic solid-state systems, such as topological superconductors.
  - • Various realistic platforms, including topological insulators, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains, have been proposed to support Majorana states based on the superconducting proximity effect.
  - • MFs are predicted to appear in tunneling spectroscopy experiments as characteristic zero-bias peaks (ZBPs).
  - • Experimental observations of ZBPs in semiconductor nanowires have been interpreted as signatures of MFs.
  - • However, these results are not definitive, and it's challenging to uniquely distinguish MFs from conventional fermionic subgap states.

• **Proposed Optical Detection Scheme for MFs:**
  - • An alternative all-optical scheme is proposed to detect MFs using a coupled hybrid quantum dot (QD) - nanomechanical resonator (NR) system with an optical pump-probe scheme.
  - • The scheme avoids direct contact between MFs and the hybrid QD-NR system, minimizing potential disturbances.
  - • The interaction between MFs and the QD is mainly due to dipole-dipole interaction, with the distance between the two systems adjustable by tens of nanometers.
  - • The QD is considered a two-level system, and once MFs appear and couple to the QD, the Majorana signature is carried out via the coherent optical spectrum of the QD.
  - • The change in the coherent optical spectrum can serve as a potential evidence for MFs in iron chains.
  - • The role of the NR in the hybrid system is further investigated using the exciton resonance spectrum, which enhances the sensitivity for detecting MFs.
  - • The technique proposed here provides a new platform for applications ranging from robust manipulation of MFs to MFs-based quantum information processing.
  - • The authors acknowledge support from various funding agencies and foundations.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Time Reversal Symmetry Violation:**
	+ First evidence found in kaon system.
	+ No other signal found to date.
	+ Studying time reversal symmetry is a cornerstone for searching physics beyond the Standard Model.
* **Theories Beyond the Standard Model:**
	+ Dynamical symmetry breaking, multi-Higgs models, spontaneous symmetry breaking, grand unified theories, extended gauge groups, supersymmetric theories, etc.
	+ Each implies specific ways of time reversal violation.
* **Hadronic Degrees of Freedom:**
	+ Effective odd nucleon-nucleon potentials or mesonic exchange potentials used to extract hadronic degrees of freedom from observables.
	+ Quark models used to relate hadronic degrees of freedom to quark degrees of freedom.
* **Charge-Exchange and Axial Vector Type Interactions:**
	+ Charge-exchange interaction is odd under time reversal and isospin transformations.
	+ Axial vector type interaction has no restriction on isospin dependence.
* **Quark Operators:**
	+ Simplest operator for odd-even vector type vertex is given by eq. (quarkv).
	+ Second generic quark operator utilizing axial vector bilinear operators is given by eq. (quarkax).
* **Constituent Quark Model:**
	+ Successful in reproducing gross features of low energy phenomena.
	+ Used to relate quark operators to effective hadronic operators.
* **Matrix Elements:**
	+ Evaluated using the Fock space representation of hadrons in terms of constituent quarks.
	+ Strong interaction potential used as a generic hybrid model connecting quark degrees of freedom with effective meson-nucleon degrees of freedom.
* **Quark Structure Effects:**
	+ Factors arising from quark structure of nucleons.
	+ Tensor coupling appears in charge-exchange interaction.
	+ Anomalous coupling factor appears in axial vector type interaction.
</summary>

	• • Characterized by a feature of quantum mechanics, essential for quantum information processing.
	• • Manipulated independently of physical realization, obeying conservation laws.

	• • Coupled through one-way exchange of photons, producing unconditional entangled states.
	• • At resonance, approaches steady state over infinite amount of time.

<summary>
• **Unification Scheme of AGN:**
  • Difference between Type 1 and Type 2 AGN explained by angle-dependent circumnuclear obscuration.
  • Obscuring dusty medium (dust torus) is optically and geometrically thick.
  • Dust absorbs UV/optical radiation and re-emits in infrared.
• **Observations and Anisotropy:**
  • Type 1 AGN show more near-IR emission than Type 2 for same intrinsic luminosity.
  • Anisotropy in IR emission depends on wavelength.
  • Probing anisotropy constrains torus models.
• **Sample and Analysis:**
  • Isotropically selected and complete sample of quasars and radio galaxies used.
  • Host-galaxy subtraction and clumpy torus models for interpretation.
  • Average SEDs of obscured (Type 2) and unobscured (Type 1) AGN shown.
• **Results and Interpretation:**
  • Radio galaxies have lower IR emission than quasars, with discrepancy largest in near-IR.
  • Difference reflects line-of-sight extinction or anisotropy in re-emission of AGN-heated dust.
  • Single absorber and emitter (dust torus) responsible for anisotropy.
• **Comparison with Previous Studies:**
  • Discrepancy with nearby Seyfert study may be due to selection criteria, luminosity, or radio-loudness.
  • Higher luminosity, radio-loud AGN show lower anisotropy.
• **Conclusions and Future Work:**
  • Observed anisotropy is consistent with intrinsic anisotropy caused by dust torus.
  • Isotropic and complete selection minimizes bias.
  • Further studies needed to understand luminosity and radio power effects on anisotropy.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Continuous Variable Quantum Key Distribution (CVQKD) Advancements**
	• • Achieved advanced improvements in theoretical analysis and experimental implementation in recent years.
	• • Practical implementation systems demonstrated, such as fiber-based Gaussian-modulated and discrete-modulated coherent-state protocol QKD systems over tens of kilometers.
	• • Unconditional security confirmed through equivalent entanglement-based (EB) scheme analysis.
• **Traditional Security Analysis Limitations**
	• • Traditional security analysis does not consider the local oscillator (LO) beam, which is necessary for balanced homodyne detection.
	• • LO beam is within Eve's manipulating domain, leaving security loopholes.
• **LO Intensity Monitoring Necessity**
	• • Monitoring LO intensity is necessary for security proofs in discrete QKD protocols embedded in continuous variables.
	• • Excess noise caused by imperfect subtraction of balanced homodyne detector (BHD) in the presence of LO intensity fluctuations has been noted and quantified.
• **Eve's LO Intensity Attack (LOIA)**
	• • Eve can intercept not only the signal beam but also the LO beam and replace the quantum channel between Alice and Bob with her own perfect quantum channel.
	• • Eve can partially hide her attack by reducing the intensity of LO with a variable attenuator, simulating fluctuation without changing LO's phase.
• **Impact of LOIA on Secret Key Rate**
	• • Eve can arbitrarily reduce channel excess noise introduced by her, making Alice and Bob underestimate Eve's intercepted information.
	• • Eve can get partial secret keys that Alice and Bob hold without being found under this attack.
• **Monitoring LO Intensity for Security**
	• • Accurate monitoring of LO intensity is necessary to confirm the security of practical CVQKD implementation.
	• • Even with monitoring, the effect of fluctuation, particularly small fluctuation, on the secret key rate is not yet clearly understood.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Code Development and Goals**
	• Developed for efficient computation of adiabatic oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions for general stellar models
	• Emphasized accuracy and flexibility in integration methods and frequency determination

• **Equilibrium Model and Variables**
	• Defined using dimensionless variables for simplicity and accuracy
	• Includes mass, radius, gravitational constant, pressure, density, and their derivatives
	• Relates to physical variables and characteristic frequencies for adiabatic oscillations
• **Displacement Vector and Equations of Adiabatic Stellar Oscillations**
	• Displacement vector written in terms of polar coordinates and spherical harmonics
	• Equations expressed in terms of dimensionless variables and frequency
	• Includes perturbed Poisson equation and Eulerian density perturbation
• **Boundary Conditions and Numerical Methods**
	• Boundary conditions at the center, surface, and for truncated models
	• Numerical methods include shooting and relaxation techniques
	• Richardson extrapolation and variational principle used for improved precision
</summary>

<summary>
• **Machine Learning in Physics**:
	• • Used to infer macroscopic properties from microscopic descriptions
	• • Identify order parameters for phase transitions, especially in complex systems
	• • Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) employed for unsupervised learning
	• • • VAEs can handle nonlinear data and scale well to large datasets
	• • • Reconstruction loss used as a universal indicator for phase transitions
• **Phase Transitions**:
	• • Occur when macroscopic properties change drastically
	• • Often involve symmetry breaking processes
	• • Order parameters help identify phases
	• • • In some systems, order parameters can only be defined in a non-local way (e.g., topological insulators)

	• • Well-studied model in physics
	• • Two-dimensional model exhibits a phase transition
	• • Order parameter: magnetization
	• • • Discrete symmetry spontaneously broken below critical temperature
• **XY Model**:
	• • Model with continuous symmetries
	• • Three-dimensional model used to test VAE's ability to classify phases
	• • Order parameter: magnetization with @xmath33-norm
	• • • Phase transition observed using unsupervised learning with VAEs

<summary>
• **Quantum Cloning Machines (QCM):**
  • Symmetric and asymmetric QCM can produce identical or non-identical copies of quantum states.
  • Universal and state-dependent QCM have different copying qualities.

• **Partial Quantum Cloning Machine (PQCM):**
  • PQCM copies only one constituent of two-partite states, useful for eavesdropping specific quantum information.
  • PQCM can also clone mixed states by using the 'purification' of the mixed state.
</summary>

* **Comparison with GR 1915+105:**
	+ GR 1915+105 has a high spin black hole
	+ IGR J17091-3624 has a low or negative spin black hole

	• Extinction curve describes how extinction changes with wavelength due to dust grains in interstellar medium.
	• CCM law is a one-parameter family of curves representing UV to IR extinction law.

• **Data and Method:**
	• Data used: UV color excesses from ANS satellite for stars of spectral types B7 and earlier.
	• Method: Improved GS method using consistent treatment of observational errors.

	• Weighted mean of @xmath0 values is 3.12.
• **Comparison with Wegner's Calibration:**
	• Difference in @xmath0 values using different @xmath46 calibrations is about 0.04.
	• Main effect on @xmath0 comes from the difference in @xmath46 values between calibrations.
• **Future Work:**
	• Extend study into other wavelength regions to check universality of CCM law.
	• Discuss the issue in a forthcoming paper.

<summary>
* **Quantum Computing with Qubits**
	+ *Qubits and Quantum Gates*
		- Qubits are the basic elements of quantum computation, with qubits and quantum logical gates allowing for the construction of any quantum algorithm.
		- The spin qubit is characterized by longer decoherence times, with manipulation done by electron spin resonance and read-out via currents in spin-polarized leads.
	+ *Qubit Encoding and Manipulation*
		- Qubits can be encoded using electron charge or spin, with the spin qubit requiring a magnetic field to remove degeneracy between spin up and down.
		- The qubit state can be controlled by external magnetic fields, spin-orbit interactions, or hyperfine interactions.
* **Triangular Qubit System**
	+ *Triangular Qubit Proposal*
		- Divincenzo et al. proposed building a qubit in a triangular system of three coherently coupled quantum dots.
		- The qubit states are encoded in the doublet subspace, which is immune to decoherence processes and can be controlled by exchange interactions.
	+ *Qubit Detection and Dynamics*
		- A new detection method, the doublet blockade effect, is proposed for reading out the qubit state using current measurement.
		- The dynamics of the qubit, including coherent and rabi oscillations, are studied, taking into account relaxation and decoherence processes.
</summary>

<summary>
• **Quantum Algorithms Efficiency**
	• Quantum superposition and interference make quantum algorithms more efficient than classical counterparts.
	• Grover's algorithm can search an item in an unsorted database quadratically faster than classical search.
	• Grover's algorithm has been realized using various physical systems like NMR, superconducting qubits, and atom-cavity QED systems.
• **Superconducting Qubits for Quantum Information Processing**
	• Superconducting qubits are attractive for quantum information processing due to their strong coupling limit in microwave cavities compared to atoms in cavity QED.
	• Squids (superconducting quantum interference devices) have been used to implement quantum algorithms due to their design flexibility, large-scale integration, and compatibility with conventional electronics.
	• Recent experiments have demonstrated the implementation of two-qubit Grover and Deutsch-Jozsa algorithms and preparation and measurement of three-qubit entanglement using superconducting qubits.
• **Three-Qubit Grover's Algorithm using Four-Level Squids in Cavity-QED**
	• The goal of this work is to implement a three-qubit Grover's algorithm using four-level squids (superconducting quantum interference devices) in a cavity-QED system.
	• The scheme is based on resonant and off-resonant interactions of the cavity field with squid transitions and application of resonant microwave pulses.
	• The scheme does not require adjustment of squid level spacing, slowly changing rabi frequencies, or second-order detuning, making it faster and more robust against decoherence.
</summary>
